home-desc: <0><0>If you feel very sick or your symptoms are not improving,</0> contact your health care provider. You can also call <2>8-1-1</2> for health advice or to get help in a different language.</0><1>For children under 2 years old, contact your health care provider directly or <2>8-1-1</2>. <5>Learn more about COVID-19 and children</5>.</1>
Tool description: Answer some questions about your symptoms to find out if a COVID-19 test is recommended. You can complete it for yourself or someone else.
Cough: Cough (either new or worsening/exacerbation of chronic cough)
DownloadAppDescription: Read the latest BC Government COVID-19 health guidance and keep your BC vaccine card and Federal COVID-19 Travel Proofs in a single place
Loss of sense of smell or taste: Loss of sense of smell or taste
Q1: Do you have any of these symptoms?
Q1-1: Severe difficulty breathing (struggling to breathe or speak)
Q1-3: Extreme fatigue (having a hard time waking up or staying awake)
Q2: Do you have any of these symptoms?
Q2-1: Difficult or impossible to lie down because you’re having trouble breathing
Q2-2: Unable to manage chronic health conditions because you’re having trouble breathing
Q4: Have you received a new COVID-19 test result?
Q4-desc: If you have not entered it here before, enter the details of your last COVID-19 test.
Q4-help: Sharing your COVID-19 test results helps public health understand and respond to COVID-19.
Q4-Enter the details: Enter the details of your COVID-19 test.
Question: Question
ResultAsymptomaticNoTest: You do not need a COVID-19 test.
ResultAsymptomaticDescription: <0>Pay attention to how you're feeling.</0> If you start developing symptoms, you can re-take the self-assessment.
ResultAsymptomaticNotice1: If you have any questions, contact your health care provider or call <1>8-1-1</1> to talk to a nurse at HealthLink BC.
ResultSymptomaticNoTest: You do not need a COVID-19 test.
ResultSymptomaticNoTestDescription1: Testing is not recommended for adults and children with mild symptoms. Stay home until you feel well enough to resume your regular activities. Avoid high risk settings (e.g. long term care facilities) and individuals at higher risk for severe complications for 10 days after the start of your symptoms.
ResultSymptomaticNoTestDescription2: If you are uncertain and/or feel very sick, call 8-1-1 or contact your primary care provider.
ResultSymptomaticNoTestNotice1: Note that sometimes symptoms may suddenly worsen and require urgent medical care.
ResultSymptomaticNoTestNotice2: Pay attention to how you are feeling. If it becomes harder to breathe, you can’t drink anything or feel much worse, call 9-1-1 or go to your nearest emergency department.
ResultSymptomaticNoTestNotice3: For more information on COVID-19 and how to stay safe, visit the <2>BCCDC website</2>.
ResultRapidTest: Stay home and away from others until you feel well enough to return to your regular activities and you do not have a fever.
ResultRapidTestDescription1: You can use a rapid COVID-19 test if you'd like.
ResultRapidTestDescription2: <0><0>Rapid antigen testing kits are free for everyone</0>. Visit your local pharmacy and ask for your testing kit.</0>
ResultRapidTestDescription3:
You can get a PCR COVID-19 test if you:

<1><0>Identify as an Indigenous person (proof of ancestry is not required), or<1>Work in health care at a hospital, long-term care facility, assisted living facility or community clinic, or<2>Work as a first responder (police officer, firefighter, emergency medical technician or paramedic), or<3>Live or work in a congregate setting, like a long-term care facility, shelter, correctional facility or group home, or<4>Live in a community that is far from testing centres and hospitals, including rural, remote, isolated or Indigenous communities or a work camp.<2><0>Find out where to get a COVID-19 test in B.C.
ResultSymptomaticTest: Please get a COVID-19 test and self-isolate.
ResultSymptomaticTestDescription1:
A positive Rapid Antigen Test (RAT) result is acceptable for initiating treatment.

<1><0>Rapid antigen testing kits are free for everyone. Visit your local pharmacy and ask for your testing kit.<2><0>If you test positive, you need to self-isolate. This means staying home and away from others.

Find out:
ResultSymptomaticTestDescription2: <0><0><0>How long you need to self-isolate</0></0><1><0>If you can access treatment for COVID-19</0></1></0>
ResultSymptomaticTestDescription3: <0><0>If you test negative,</0> you should stay home until you feel well enough to return to your regular activities. If your symptoms do not improve or they get worse, you should take another rapid test and get health advice:</0><1><0>Contact your health care provider</0>OR<2>Call <1>8-1-1</1> to talk to a nurse at HealthLink BC</2></1><2>If you start to feel very sick (for example, if you're having trouble breathing or can't drink anything), call 9-1-1 or visit an <1>Urgent and Primary Care Centre (UPCC)</1> or emergency department right away.</2>
ResultSymptomaticTestNotice:
<0><0>Pay attention to how you're feeling. If your symptoms change, you should get health advice:<1><0>Contact your health care provider
OR <1>Call 8-1-1 to talk to a nurse at HealthLink BC<2>Call 9-1-1 or visit an <2>Urgent and Primary Care Centre or emergency department right away if you start to feel very sick - for example, if it gets hard to breathe or you can't drink anything.
Result811Notice: <0>Contact your health care provider or call <1>8-1-1</1> to talk to a nurse at HealthLink BC.</0><1><0>Pay attention to how you're feeling.</0> If you start to feel very sick (for example, if you're having trouble breathing or can't drink anything), call 9-1-1 or visit an <3>Urgent and Primary Care Centre (UPCC)</3> emergency department right away.</1>
Result911: Your symptoms require emergency medical care.
Result911Description: <0>Call 9-1-1 or visit an <1>Urgent and Primary Care Centre (UPCC)</1> or emergency department right away.</0>
HWQ1: Are you moderately to severely immunocompromised?
HWQ1-1: You’ve had an organ transplant and are taking anti-rejection medications
HWQ1-2: You’ve had a bone marrow or stem cell transplant
HWQ1-3: You are receiving treatment for cancer
HWQ1-4: You’ve been diagnosed with a moderate to severe primary immunodeficiency disorder
HWQ1-5: You have advanced or untreated HIV
HWQ1-6: You are on dialysis and/or have severe kidney disease
HWQ1-7: You are on active treatment with immunosuppressive therapies
HWQ2: Do you have any one of the following conditions?
HWQ2-2: You have severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or asthma requiring hospitalization in the last year
HWQ2-3: You are taking biologics for asthma, severe lung disease and have at least one of the following: on long-term home oxygen, are being assessed for a lung transplant, have severe pulmonary arterial hypertension, severe pulmonary fibrosis, or severe interstitial lung disease
HWQ2-4: You’ve been diagnosed with a rare blood disorder or inborn error of metabolism
HWQ2-5: You’ve had a splenectomy or you have functional asplenia
HWQ2-6: You have diabetes and are being treated with insulin
HWQ2-7: You have a significant developmental disability
HWQ2-8: You have a condition or syndrome that causes muscle weakness around the lungs requiring the use of a ventilator or continuous bi-PAP
HWQ2-9: You are on dialysis or have stage 5 chronic kidney disease (eGFR ≤ 15ml/min)
HWQ3-desc: This information helps us find the best testing options for you.
HWQ4-desc: This information helps us find the best testing options for you. Proof of ancestry is not required.
HWQ5-desc: This information helps us find the best testing options for you.
HWQ5-2: 1 or 2 doses of Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca or Novavax
HWQ5-4: Initial vaccination series and a booster dose
HWQ7-M: Do you have 3 or more chronic conditions?
HWQ7-desc: Examples of chronic conditions include:<1><0>Obesity</0><1>Diabetes</1><2>Heart failure</2><3>Chronic respiratory condition</3><4>Kidney disease</4><5>Previous stroke</5></1>
HWQ7-S: Do you have 1 or more chronic conditions?
